page.title: Portrait of a Man with a Beer Jug

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = | image_file = Frans Hals - portrait of a man holding a beer jug.jpg | caption = ''Portrait of a man with a beer jug'', c.1630 Oil on canvas, 83 cm x 66 cm | painting_alignment = | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Frans Hals]] | catalogue = [[Seymour Slive]], Catalog 1974: #74 | year = {{start date|1630}} <!--remove date template if before 1583 CE --> | material = Oil on canvas | subject = | height_metric = 83 | width_metric = 66 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. --> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. --> | condition = | city = | museum = Private collection | accession = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = | url = <!--{{URL|example.com}} Only for official web pages--> }} '''''Portrait of a man with a beer jug''''' is a painting by the [[Dutch Golden Age painter]] [[Frans Hals]], painted in the early 1630s, now in a private collection.
==Painting == This painting was documented by [[Seymour Slive]] in 1974, who claimed that it was in the collection of [[Henry Reichhold]] in White Plains, New York.<ref>Frans Hals, by Seymour Slive, 1974 a catalog raisonné of Hals works by Seymour Slive: Volume Three, the catalogue, National gallery of Art: Kress Foundation, Studies in the History of European Art, London - Phaidon Press, 1974, catalog #74, pp. 44-45</ref> The figure of a red deer on the front of the beer jug corresponds with the house name "Het Rode Hert" of the Haarlem beer brewer [[Cornelis Guldewagen]], whose portrait was painted by Hals in 1660. Though the genre of the work is similar to works painted by Hals in the early thirties, the rough brush strokes are more similar to his work in the sixties. Possibly, the man with the jug and Guldewagen himself are the same:
<gallery mode=packed widths="250" heights="250"> File:Frans Hals - portrait of a man holding a beer jug.jpg File:Frans Hals Guldewagen.jpg </gallery>
In an old genre painting of [[Haarlem]] from the 1650s, a man is transporting beer jugs with a horse-drawn sled. The jugs have a red deer on them, the symbol of Guldewagen's brewery:<ref>Research on catalog nr. 67 "Cornelis Guldewagen", by C.A. van Hees for ''Frans Hals'', Exhibition catalog, 1962 for the Frans Hals Museum, title : Exhibition on the Occasion of the Centenary of the Municipal Museum at Haarlem, 1862-1962, exhibition committee: H.P. Baard, Seymour Slive, A.B. de Vries</ref> <gallery mode=packed widths="250" heights="250"> File:Jan Wouwerman - St. Bavokerk from the southeast.jpg|[[St. Bavochurch]] from the Southeast, by [[Jan Wouwerman]] File:Zuiderhofje Haarlem oude bierkruik.JPG|Old Haarlem beer jug in the [[Zuiderhofje]] </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Frans Hals}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} [[File:Pulchri Studio Den Haag.jpg|thumb|220px|Pulchri Studio facade.]] [[File:Pulcri Studio Expo Abel.jpg|thumb|Exhibition of sculpture by Mexican artist [[Abel Ramírez Águilar]].]] '''Pulchri Studio''' ([[Latin language|Latin]]:"For the study of beauty") is a Dutch art society, art institution and art studio based in [[The Hague]] ('s-Gravenhage), [[Netherlands]].<ref name=Sillevis>{{cite book|last=Sillevis|first=John|title=Dutch Drawings from the Age of Van Gogh: From the Collection of the Haags Gemeentemuseum|year=1993|publisher=Premier Book Marketing Ltd.|isbn=0-915577-24-0|pages=11|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=b4A-T6fEJsG5hAfPvsHCBQ&sqi=2&hl=cs&id=Zh9QAAAAMAAJ&dq=Pulchri+Studio+1847&q=Latin#search_anchor}}</ref>
This institute began in 1847 at the home of painter [[Netherlandse kunstschilders|Lambertus Hardenberg]]. Since 1893 the club has its residence in the villa at ''Lange Voorhout 15'' in The Hague, which is currently a brownish aubergine color. There are accepted as members artistically working members (painters, sculptors and photographers) and art lovers. The members will be selected from a given by the general committee.
An artist membership allows the artist to exhibit his own works in the galleries of the Company. These so-called sales exhibitions have passed since the founding of the association until today integral part of this institution! Art lovers have to be invited by other members. The association leases its properties even to nonmembers, too.
==Origins== [[File:Paul Gabriël - Molen bij een plas.jpg|thumb|Paul Gabriël: Windmill in a pond.]] The unspoilt countryside around even the rich coastal town of [[The Hague]]<ref>At that time was The Hague was considered the most beautiful village in Europe.</ref> with its rural environment and the unspoiled landscape and nature and the nearby fishing village of [[Scheveningen]] attracted many young artists.<ref>The small spots like Loosduinen, Voorburg and Wassenaar were quite popular because of their virginity.</ref> The artists wanted to be far away from the state-run requirements of art ([[neo-classicism]]) and liked to decide their own way. The model was the successful artist colony of [[Barbizon]] south of Paris in the forest of [[Fontainebleau]]. The unaltered life of the people and the unspoilt polders and the [[North Sea]] coast played an important role. They wanted to be far away from the beginning in the Netherlands industrialisation in [[Amsterdam]] and [[Rotterdam]].
==History== [[File:Diligentia - 's-Gravenhage - 20091090 - RCE.jpg|thumb|Diligentia.]] [[File:Interieur, overzicht van de antichambrezaal met kunstexpositie - 's-Gravenhage - 20407039 - RCE.jpg|thumb|Exhibition with a view to the entrance.]] Following the abolition of the [[patronage]] for artist they were searching for a new way. The city of 's-Gravenhage (The Hague) with its surroundings and the coastal landscape of the [[North Sea]] at [[Scheveningen]] became attractive for young painters. In 1847 with the establishment of the association Pulchri Studio such a new approach has been emerged. These artist's association is a typical Dutch development.<ref>In the Netherlands the concept of ''societät'' or ''cooperative'' was practised. They are known as the guild of Sin Lucas, which was for the Painters. At the end of the eighteenth century they discontonued.</ref> It stands in the continuation of the tradition of the old academies of the 17th and 18th centuries.<ref>The old academy has nothing in common with the new one.</ref><ref>Since the rule of Napoleon these academies were completely under state control and the local teaching conception. And these new cooperatives meant the outbreak of these artists, linked to the freedom of genre and color palette. They wanted to determine the expressiveness of the colors by themselves.</ref><ref>Pulchri Studio developed for the resident artists' colonies of The Hague, Laren and the estate Oosterbeek the center and was also the linking of creativity, the contact with each other and the world outside, too.</ref> A special role has played gatherings, which were called ''art considerations'' (Kunstbeschouwingen). They offered the artists the opportunity to present their own works the other members and to exchange information with the other painters. This way of handling the works creators as an ''Apprentice'' with other artists as ''Master'' has been the guarantee of the success of the Hague School.<ref>The Hague School ultimately became synonymous with the famous [[Dutch Impressionism]]. The [[Amsterdam School|Amsterdam Impressionism]], as [[Allebé|School of Allebé]] references, was ultimately the continuation of this trend.</ref> The location served as a studio and workshop. Right at the beginning this cooperative had no exhibition rooms. Alternatively the painters participated in the two or three-yearly ''Exhibition of Living Masters''.<ref>This exhibition had been a touring exhibition.</ref><ref>This exhibition at the Kingdom of the united Netherlands was very important. She was the only way for the still unknown painters to be become known at all in the home.</ref> – In 1882, [[Vincent van Gogh]] participated in such an art appreciation along with Bosboom and Henkes. The location had the function of the social contact to the native population. It wasn't only a place of social encounter, but at the same time it offered to the artists the opportunity to communicate with collectors and dealers. – This was very important.
Among the founding members of ''Pulchri'' has been [[Netherlandse kunstschilder|Lambertus Hardenberg]], [[Willem Roelofs]], [[Jan Hendrik Weissenbruch]] and [[Bartholomeus Johannes van Hove]]. In 1847, Van Hove has been the first chairman of the artists association. Short time later King [[William II of the Netherlands|Willem II.]] took over the [[patron]]age.<ref>This attached particular importance to the location seat of the government and the king.</ref> A short time later [[Johannes Bosboom]], [[Jozef Israels]], [[Hendrik Willem Mesdag]], [[Jan Weissenbruch]] and some lesser-known artists joined Pulchri. Subsequent significant members are also [[Jan Sluyters]], [[Paul Citroen]] and [[Jan Willem Sluiter|Willy Sluiter]].
Many painters, who are today attributed to the [[Hague School]], had position on the board and made this cooperative to a stronghold: Bosboom was chairman from 1852 to 1853, Israëls from 1875–1878 and Mesdag from 1898–1907. But even [[Jacob Maris]] and [[Willem Maris]], [[Anton Mauve]], [[Roelofs]] and [[Jan Weissenbruch]] were members of the executive committee. They were responsible for the ''drawing room'', the ''art considerations'' or the ''social meetings''.
The growing membership forced the organizers to expand and in 1901 it was moved to the building on the Lange Voorhout 15.
In 2004, a number of works from Pulchri were stolen, later recovered in 2007.<ref name="Cirque de Pepin">{{cite web|last=Cirque de Pepin|title=H.M.S. is back|url=http://www.cirque.nl/info/news_archive.html|work=OKT 2007|publisher=Cirque.nl|accessdate=17 February 2012}}</ref>
==The two rival cooperatives== [[File:A town on the river Vecht by Theophile de Bock (1851-1904).jpg|thumb|Théophile de Bock (1895/1905): A town on the river Vecht – private collection.]] During its turbulent history were attempts at secession or counter companies. None of them should never attain the importance of Pulchri Studion. But this is an indication that politics of these cooperative is not always met with broad approval. One of these countermovements is the [[Haagse Kunstkring]]. In 1891 this cooperative was created by the painter [[Théophile de Bock]] and the architect [[Paul du Rieu]].<ref>Haagse Kunstkring means loosely translated: ''[[The Hague Art Circle]]''.</ref> It has remained until now and has been awarded to its centenary with the medal of the city of The Hague.
In The Hague in the year 1884 a smaller Artists Association – [[Arti et Industriae]] was established. Their aim is to promote Dutch art craft and has a pension fund, too. From the beginning it is more oriented towards the subject to industry and industrial progress. So it has a completely different orientation than the Hague School with her Pulchri Studio, which wanted to immortalize the untouched nature and the genuine life in the country, the podern and on the coast. – Thus it should never attain the significance and charisma as Pulchri Studio. Arti et Industriae had set oneself the goal of contact and coordination. They organizes exhibitions, too. However, their existence was secured by the proximity to the seat of government.
==Pulchri Studio and the Art Academy== From the Hague School and the [[Royal Academy of Art, The Hague]] went a favorable effect on the development of the artists association ''Pulchri Studio''. This society took over the function for the promotion of the fine arts. In this environment were excellent teachers and students.<ref>In 1682, this Academy was initially founded as a school of art and it is the oldest [[art school]] of the Netherlands, too. Through a private initiative, it has been established.</ref> The place of The Hague and its surroundings was and is important because of the seat of the government. At the Art Academy Blosboom, Willem Maris, Johan Hendrik Weissenbruch and Georg Breitner were also trained.
==Pulchri Studio and the Hollandsche Teekenmaatschappij== The cooperative of Pulchri Studio was open to new technics in painting in the fine art. This resulted in the panel painting to another movement within the Dutch Impressionism, the Hague School.
In [[Bruxelles|Brussels]] in the year 1855 the Society for [[watercolour]]-painting, the "Société Belge des watercolorist" was founded.<ref>[http://www.rkd.nl/en/ RKD Netherlands Institute for Art History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704121422/https://rkd.nl/en/ |date=4 July 2015 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.arba-esa.be/ Académie Royale des Beaux-Arts de Bruxelles]</ref> She was quite successful. This movement was an expression of social and country-specific implementation of the very successful work of [[The Royal Watercolour Society]] to London. Precisely because of the contacts with the environment of the "Académie Royale des Beaux-Arts de Bruxelles", the watercolours were attractive again as a version of the painting for artists. Indeed, this watercolour technique had reached their third heyday from the end of the 19th century to the early 20th century.<ref>An important influence came from [[August Macke]] and [[Paul Klee]]. During their tunisian travel in 1914 they had chosen this painting technique in [[watercolour]]s. The artists wanted to show the very bright luminous intensity over there.</ref><ref>Kandisky from the expressionist community [[Blauer Reiter|Blue Rider]] from [[München|Munich]] also took care of the watercolour painting. As part of the art movement of [[avant-garde]] he led the watercolour painting to a new meaning.</ref>
On 31 January 1878 the ''[[Hollandsche Teekenmaatschappij]]'' (in English: Dutch Drawing Society) was founded. Its founding members belonged to the core of the ''Hague School'' – the movement of the ''Dutch Impressionism'' and thus the Pulchri Studio. The society was so organized that it was independent, but closely linked to Pulchri Studio remained. Its honorary members included painters from Belgium, Germany and Italy.
In 1901, this society ceased to exist.
==Policy and Pulchri Studio== The Society Pulchri wasn't as conservative as [[Arti et Amicitiae]] to [[Amsterdam]]. Yes, they even rejected the traditional painting styles.
In the royal capital of 's-Gravenhage (The Hague) his caused an uproar and a political issue, too. By the king [[William III of the Netherlands|Willem III]] Hermanus Koekkoek had received a medal in recognition of a work. From Pulchri came the objection that this painting would no longer correspond to the current state of the art.<ref>In this context, the chapter ''A world of light'', P. 7 – 32, ''Impressionism, an international art movement from 1860 to 1920'' referred by Norma Broude is very informative. Here it can be seen how much the conflict was between the '''shaking off''' the [[neoclassicism]] and [[romanticism]] and the '''retention''' of the tradition of craft and the old ways. – The [[landscape painting]] of [[Dutch Golden Age|"The 1. Golden Age of the Netherlands"]] is precisely that tradition, which was rejected by them.</ref> – In public, the Hague School took the opposite position and stood against the official art policy of the Dutch king. This was notably represented by Artzt, de Bock, Bosboom, Israëls, Jacob and Willem Maris, Mauve, Mesdag and Neuhuys.
In addition they made known that neither one may send them a tender for an art competition nor they will take part in a competition any more.<ref>One relied on the strength of Puchri Studion and her reputation in the country and abroad.</ref> <ref>Bley, Britta: Vom Staat zur Nation (in German) – From the state to the nation, page 124-125.</ref>
In the circles that represented the new, radical painting style of impressionism or were only open, it was believed to have triggered something. In those days the queen tried to calm things down by their commitment to Pulchi. There was a no significant change in the policy of the king. – The disappointment was very big and they had to choose their own way.<ref>The existence of Pulchri today and the very well known [[Museum Mesdag]] was the best proof.</ref>
==Notable members: 19th century== [[File:Wintergezicht met ondergaande zon tussen geboomte Rijksmuseum SK-A-4916.jpeg|thumb|Louis Apol: Winter landscape with sunset between trees (Rijksmuseum).]] [[File:Johannes Joseph Destree Strand bei Scheveningen 1871.jpg|thumb|Johannes Joseph Destree: Beach of Scheveningen (1871)]] [[File:Taco Mesdag Molentje Leende.jpg|thumb|Taco Mesdag: Molentje Leende (1880)]] * [[Anna Adelaïde Abrahams]] (1849 – 1930) * [[Louis Apol]] (1850–1936) * [[Gerard Bilders]] (1836–1865) * [[Bernardus Johannes Blommers]] (1845–1904)) * [[Johannes Bosboom]] (1817–1891) * [[George Hendrik Breitner]] (1857–1923)<ref>Georg Hendrik Breitener was the forerunner of the Amsterdam Impressionism as part of the international movement of impressionism. He was a painter of panel painting and a pioneer of photography. He left about 2.000 negatives.</ref> * [[Johannes Josephus Destrée]] (1827–1886) * [[Jan Hendrik Doeleman|Johan Hendrik Doeleman]] (1848–1913) * [[Paul Gabriël]] (1828–1903) * [[Arnold Marc Gorter]] (1866–1937) * {{ill|Hendrik Haverman|nl}} (1857–1928) * [[Bartholomeus Johannes van Hove]] (1790–1880) * [[Bramine Hubrecht]] (1855-1913) * [[Jozef Israëls]] (1827–1919) * [[Jan Philip Koelman]] (1818–1893) * {{ill|Johannes Diederikus Kruseman|nl}} (1835–1895) * [[Jacob Maris]] (1837–1899) * [[Willem Maris]] (1844–1910) * [[Anton Mauve]] (1838–1888) * [[Geesje Mesdag-van Calcar]] (1850–1936) * [[Hendrik Willem Mesdag]] (1831–1915) * [[Taco Mesdag]] (1829–1902) * [[Sina van Houten]] (1834–1909) * [[Dutch painter|Willem Cornelis Rip]] (1856–1922) * [[Willem Roelofs]] (1822–1897) * [[Julius van de Sande Bakhuyzen]] (1835–1925) * [[Andreas Schelfhout]] (1787–1870) * {{ill|Piet Schipperius|nl}} (1840–1929) * [[Hendrik Jacobus Scholten]] (1824–1907) * [[Jan Sluijters]] (1881–1957) * [[Jan Willem Sluiter (Kunstmaler)|Willem Sluiter]] (1873–1949) * [[Pieter Stortenbeker]] (1828–1898) * [[Johannes Gijsbert Vogel]] (1828–1915) * [[Jan Weissenbruch]] (1822–1880) * [[Jan Hendrik Weissenbruch]] (1824–1903) * [[Jan Hillebrand Wijsmuller]] (1855–1925)

File:A winter landscape with houses along a canal by Jan Hillebrand Wijsmuller (1855-1925).jpg|Jan Hillebrand Wijsmuller (undated): A winter landscape with houses along a canal, private collection. </gallery></center>
== Revival after the war == After the Second World War was ''Pulchri Studio'' in disrepute: In 1943, the executive committee had submitted the order from Berlin to join the Reich-Chamber of Culture (Reichskulturkammer). In the Kingdom of the Netherlands this act was regarded as an act of collaboration. – After 1945 the chairman at that time, Willy Sluiter, was dismissed. In 1996 Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Beatrix]] just took the patronage of this artists association and helped her back to the traditional reputation and importance in the art scene of The Hague and the Netherlands.
==Notable members: 20th century==

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Salomon van Ruysdael - River Landscape with Ferry - Google Art Project.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = River Landscape with Ferry | artist = [[Salomon van Ruysdael]] | year = 1649 | material = | height_metric = 101.5 | width_metric = 134.8 | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | city = [[Washington D.C.]] | museum = [[National Gallery of Art]] | owner = }} '''''River Landscape with Ferry''''' (1649) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Salomon van Ruysdael]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[National Gallery of Art]] in Washington D.C.. This painting was owned by [[Jacques Goudstikker]] and was restituted to his heirs in 2006.<ref>[https://rkd.nl/explore/images/17034 River Landscape with Ferry] in the [[RKD]]</ref>
Jacques Goudstikker was a Jewish art dealer whose works were seized and taken to Germany after his death as part of war booty. The painting was restituted to the Netherlands after the war ([[Rijksdienst voor het Cultureel Erfgoed|RCE]]). It was lent by the RCE to various museums on long-term loans before being given to the [[Rijksmuseum]] in 1960, where it had featured in its Gallery of Honor for years. The painting was selected as one of 120 highlights in the booklet ''[[120 Paintings from the Rijksmuseum]]''.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/album120tableaux00rijkuoft#page/n52/mode/1up 2083A4] in the "Album: 120 (Tableaux du) / (Schilderijen uit het) / Paintings from the Rijksmuseum", Opening hours and table of titles of 120 black & white illustrations of paintings in English, Dutch, and French, paperback tourist guide c. 1950-1990, Rijksmuseum Amsterdam</ref>
In 2006 it was finally restored to the Goudstikker heirs and since 2007 it has been part of the collection of the National Gallery of Art. It was part of an exhibition ''Reclaimed: paintings from the collection of Jacques Goudstikker'' in 2008.<ref>[http://www.codart.nl/exhibitions/details/1723/ Article] on [[codart]]</ref>
This scene is similar to other river landscape paintings Ruisdael made in this period and these often served as inspiration for later painters of landscape. <gallery> File:Salomon van Ruisdael 002.jpg|[[Alte Pinakothek]], 1639 File:Rivierlandschap met een veerboot Rijksmuseum SK-C-1698.jpeg|[[Rijksmuseum]], 1649 File:Salomon van Ruysdael - Paisagem Fluvial com Balsa Transportando Animais.jpg|[[São Paulo Museum of Art]], c. 1650 </gallery>
== References == {{reflist}} *[http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/Collection/art-object-page.139458.html Article] on museum website
{{Commons category|Paintings of river landscapes by Salomon van Ruysdael}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:River Landscape with Ferry}} [[Category:1649 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Salomon van Ruysdael]] [[Category:Collections of the National Gallery of Art]] [[Category:Cattle in art]] [[Category:Maritime paintings]]

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=October 2018}} {{refimprove|date=October 2018}}
'''The New Zealand Dance Company''' (incorporated as The New Zealand Dance Advancement Trust) is an [[Auckland]] based, nationally focused contemporary dance company.
Established in 2011, by co-founders Chief Executive/Artistic Director (and [[Arts Foundation of New Zealand|Arts Laureate]]) Shona McCullagh and the founding General Manager Frances Turner, the company sought to break the paradigm of dance companies operating on a project by project basis, presenting work by one choreographer, and moved instead to a sustainable model of presenting a variety of choreographic works.
== Productions ==
Language of Living was The New Zealand Dance Company's first production and is composed of five short works by [[New Zealand]] choreographers.
Dreamy McFloat was choreographed by Tupua Tigafua and has music by Richard M Moyle, [[Antonio Vivaldi]], and a poem excerpt from [[John Pule]], Little Sun. Tenerezza was choreographed by Michael Parmenter, with music by [[Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach|C.P.E Bach]]. Human Human God was choreographed by Sarah Foster-Sproull, with music by Eden Mullholland.
Language of Living opened in 2012 at the [[Aotea Centre]] in [[Auckland]]. In 2013 Language of Living toured the [[North Island]] of [[New Zealand]], The New Zealand Dance Company performed in [[Auckland]], [[Warkworth, New Zealand|Warkworth]], [[Whangarei]], [[Orewa]], [[Hawkes Bay]] and [[Wellington]]. In 2014 Language of Living toured in New Zealand, performing in [[Invercargill]], [[Christchurch]], [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]], [[New Plymouth]] and [[Tauranga]].
Rotunda is The New Zealand Dance Company's second production, and its first full-length work.
Rotunda<ref>{{cite web|last=Whyte|first=Raewyn|title=Virtual Rotunda Unites Modern Dance and Brass Band Music|url=http://www.theatreview.org.nz/reviews/review.php?id=6236|publisher=Theatre Review|accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> is the first major work for the New Zealand Dance Company. It was choreographed by Shona McCullagh.
==Dancers ==
* Justin Haiu<ref>{{cite web|last=Haiu|first=Justin|title=Acclaimed Show Coming to Nelson|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/nelson-mail/entertainment/9974927/Acclaimed-show-coming-to-Nelson|accessdate=24 April 2014}}</ref> * Tupua Tigafua<ref>{{cite web|last=Tigafua|first=Tupua|title=Dacer/Choreographer Tupua Tigafua|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/standing-room-only/audio/2593810/dancer-choreographer,-tupua-tigafua|publisher=Radio New Zealand National|accessdate=27 April 2014}}</ref> * Gareth Okan * Carl Tolentino * Hannah Tasker-Poland * Lucy Lynch * Chrissy Kokiri<ref>{{cite web|last=Kokiri|first=Chrissy|title=Dancing the Language of Living|url=http://thewireless.co.nz/articles/dancing-for-mana-wahine|publisher=The Wireless NZ|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> * Katie Rudd<ref>{{cite web|last=Rudd|first=Katie|title=A part of our life force|url=http://thewireless.co.nz/articles/dancing-for-mana-wahine|publisher=Taranaki Daily News|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref>
== Management ==
* Chief Executive/Artistic Director - Shona McCullagh * General Manager - Melanie Esplin<ref>{{cite web|last=Eslpin|first=Melanie|title=New General Manager for The New Zealand Dance Company|url=http://www.thebigidea.co.nz/connect/media-releases/2014/feb/139035-new-general-manager-for-the-new-zealand-dance-company|publisher=The Big Idea, te aria nui|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> * Company Manager - Roger Christensen * Administrative Assistant - Anna Simpson
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nzdc.org.nz/ The New Zealand Dance Company]

{{Infobox University | name = Tyler School of Art | image_size = 200px | caption =The Tyler School of Art's main building on the campus of Temple University | latin_name = | motto = | established = 1935
{{small|(as Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts)}} | type = Art and architecture school | faculty = | president = | students =1,550 | city = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] | state = [[Pennsylvania]] | country = United States | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | affiliations = | footnotes = | website = https://tyler.temple.edu | address = | photo = |parent=Temple University|dean=Susan E. Cahan|image=}} The '''Tyler School of Art''' is an art and architecture school based at [[Temple University]], a large, urban, public research university in [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania.{{Cite web|url=https://www.temple.edu/academics/schools-and-colleges|title=Schools and Colleges {{!}} Temple University|website=www.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-14}} Tyler currently enrolls about 1,350 undergraduate students and about 200 graduate students in a wide variety of academic degree programs, including architecture; art education; art history; art therapy; ceramics; city and regional planning; community arts practices; community development; facilities management; fibers and material studies; glass; graphic and interactive design; historic preservation; horticulture; landscape architecture; metals/jewelry/CAD-CAM; painting; photography; sculpture; and visual studies.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/academic-programs|title=Academic Programs|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}} Tyler's art programs "have long been considered among the finest in the nation."{{Cite book|title=Temple University: 125 Years of Service to Philadelphia, the Nation, and the World|last=Hilty|first=James|publisher=Temple University Press|year=2010|isbn=1439900191|location=|pages=227}} The school is currently No. 15 in the nation among fine arts schools in U.S. News' Best Graduate Schools rankings, and three of Tyler's individual MFA programs are ranked in the top 10.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-fine-arts-schools/fine-arts-rankings|title=U.S. News Best Fine Arts Programs|last=|first=|date=October 14, 2018|website=U.S. News & World Report|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Founded in 1935 by Stella Elkins Tyler and sculptor [[Boris Blai]] in nearby [[Elkins Park, Pennsylvania|Elkins Park,]] Pennsylvania{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/history-vision|title=Mission, Vision and Values|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}}, Tyler moved to a new, 255,000-square-foot facility at Temple's Main Campus in 2009 with the cornerstone financial support of an allocation of $61.5 million from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/tyler-move-creates-temple-arts-hot-spot|title=Tyler move creates Temple arts hot spot|date=2009-02-05|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}}. In 2012, Tyler's Department of Architecture moved into a new facility connected to the main Tyler building.{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/department-architecture-moves-new-building|title=Architecture moves into dedicated building|date=2012-01-26|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}} Temple's departments of Landscape Architecture & Horticulture (based primarily at Temple's suburban Ambler Campus) and Planning & Community Development joined Tyler in 2016, unifying all of the university's built-environment design disciplines in one school for the first time. In 2017, arts administrator, art historian and curator Susan E. Cahan, formerly associate dean and dean for the arts at [[Yale College]] at [[Yale University]], was appointed dean of the Tyler School of Art by Temple President Richard M. Englert.{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/2017-05-08/tyler-school-art-dean-named|title=Susan E. Cahan appointed dean of Tyler School of Art|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}} == Academic programs and accreditation== The Tyler School of Art offers a wide range of degree and certificate programs in the areas of art, built-environment design, graphic design, art history and art education. Tyler students also have access to the comprehensive programs and resources of Temple University. Under Susan E. Cahan, Tyler's dean since 2017, Tyler has placed a renewed emphasis on cross-disciplinary studies and collaboration in its academic and co-curricular programs.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/meet-tyler-dean-susan-cahan|title=Meet Tyler dean Susan Cahan|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}} Tyler's academic degree programs: * Architecture (BSArch, MArch, MSArch**) * Art (BA, available only at [[Temple University, Japan Campus]]) * Art Education (BFA with art education concentration, BSEd, MEd with major in art education) * Art History (BA, MA, MA with fine arts administration track, PhD) * Art Therapy (BA) * Ceramics (BFA*, MFA) * City & Regional Planning (MS) * Community Development (BS) * Facilities Management (BS) * Facilities Planning (MS***) * Fibers & Material Studies (BFA*, MFA) * Foundations (non-degree granting program for freshmen) * Glass (BFA*, MFA) * Graphic & Interactive Design (BFA*, MFA) * Historic Preservation (BS) * Horticulture (BSHort, ASHort) * Landscape Architecture (BSLA, MLArch) * Metals/Jewelry/CAD-CAM (BFA*, MFA) * Painting (BFA*, MFA) * Photography (BFA*, MFA) * Printmaking (BFA*, MFA) * Sculpture (BFA*, MFA) * Visual Studies (BA) * also available as BFA with Entrepreneurial Studies or a BFA with Art Education concentration ** post-professional degree available with optional concentrations in Advanced Technologies and Design, Urban Ecologies and Design, Health and Design *** post-professional degree available with an optional concentration in Health and Design Tyler also offers undergraduate certificate programs in Arts in Community, Creative Entrepreneurship, Environmental Sustainability, Historic Preservation, Horticultural Therapy, Landscape Plants, Native Perennial Garden Design and Sustainable Food Systems; and graduate certificate programs in Arts in Community, Health Facilities Planning, Sustainable Community Planning and Transportation Planning. The Tyler School of Art at Temple University is a non-profit, accredited member of the [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]] and the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]]. Tyler's MArch degree program is accredited by the [[National Architectural Accrediting Board]], and the school's BLArch and MLArch programs are accredited by the National Landscape Architecture Board and the Landscape Architecture Accreditation Board. Tyler's MS program in City and Regional Planning is accredited by the Planning Accreditation Board. The BS program in Facilities Management is accredited by the International Facilities Management Association.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/accreditation|title=Accreditation|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}} == Facilities == Since 2009, when the Tyler School of Art moved into its new home, a 250,000-square-foot building designed by award-winning architect Carlos Jiménez{{Cite web|url=https://carlosjimenezstudio.com/tyler-school-of-art/|title=Tyler School of Art (2005-2009)|website=Carlos Jiménez Studio|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-14}}, Tyler's art students and faculty have had access to expansive, state-of-the-art facilities. Tyler's architecture students and faculty experienced a similar boost in size and quality of facilities when the program moved into a new, 50,000-square-foot Architecture Building in 2012—Temple's first building dedicated solely to architecture. The two structures, which are connected by a glass-enclosed passageway, are located at Temple University's Main Campus in Philadelphia, giving the Tyler community access to the city's museums, galleries and other arts-related resources. Their location adjacent to Presser Hall (part of Temple University's [[Boyer college of music and dance|Boyer College of Music and Dance]]) and Temple Theaters (part of Temple's School of Theater, Film and Media Arts) has created an arts quadrant in the northeast corner of campus. The central courtyard between Tyler's two primary buildings is one of the largest green spaces at Temple University's Main Campus. In 2018, the Nicholas Kripal Natural Dye Garden, a collaboration between students and faculty in Tyler's Fibers & Materials Studies and Landscape Architecture programs, was installed in the courtyard, part of a plan to re-activate the courtyard and make it a space for interdisciplinary collaboration and recreation.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/TylerSchool/status/1044285110596632577|title=Tyler School of Art on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} Notable Tyler facilities include: * The Architecture Building, with four floors of studios and exposed air ducts, plumbing pipes and lights in order for students to observe the building's infrastructure.{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/facilities|title=Explore Our Facilities {{!}} Tyler School of Art|website=tyler.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}} * A 10,000-square foot ceramics facility—one of the largest in the nation—with four gas kilns, 13 electric kilns, a large glaze room and 3-D modeling and printing facilities. * Fibers and material studies studios equipped with a computer lab for silk screening and digital printing, a Jacquard Loom, multi-harness floor looms and electronic looms.{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/programs/fibers-material-studies|title=Fibers & Material Studies|website=Tyler School of Art|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} * A glass facility with a hot shop with two 530-pound day tanks, four benches and four glory holes; and a cold shop with Merker and Czech lathes and four flameworking stations. * Landscape architecture and horticulture facilities at Temple University's large Ambler Campus in suburban Montgomery County, which include a 187-acre Ambler Arboretum and a 5,600 square foot greenhouse.{{Cite web|url=https://ambler.temple.edu/arboretum/gardens|title=Gardens {{!}} Ambler Campus|website=ambler.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}} * A 5,600-square-foot metals/jewelry/CAD-CAM facility with 56 bench-top torches, three burn-out ovens, a computer lab, a crucible, a centrifuge, two 3-D printers and more. * Painting and drawing rooms, each measuring more than 1,000 square feet with north-facing, floor-to-ceiling windows providing ideal light and views of Philadelphia. * A 9,000-square foot photography facility with two large wet labs, a lighting studio, a critique room, an exhibition gallery, computer studios with large-format printing and more. * A fully equipped, 10,000-square-foot printmaking facility featuring three large rooms for lithography, etching/relief/monoprinting and screen printing. * A 16,000-square-foot sculpture space, including a complete wood shop and metal fabrication shop, two-ton gantry cranes, hoists, an outdoor assembly area and a 1000-square-foot outdoor pad. * Digital services facilities that include a Digital Fabrications Studio where students have access to 3-D printers, 3-D scanning, vinyl cutting, laser cutting and a ten-needle embroidery machine; a Media Output Center with archival-quality printing up to 64 inches wide; and a Visual Resource Center with a wide variety of scanners, projectors, DSLR cameras and more.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/tyler-digital-services|title=Tyler Digital Services|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} == Temple Contemporary and public programming == Temple Contemporary is Tyler's exhibitions and public programs unit, which has been led by Robert Blackson, Tyler's director of exhibitions and public programming, since 2011.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/who-we-are|title=Who We Are|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}} Temple Contemporary's galleries and offices are located in the Tyler building at Temple University's Main Campus, although much of its programming takes place in the surrounding Philadelphia community. Temple Contemporary's mission is "to re-imagine the social function of art through questions of local relevance and international significance.”{{Cite web|url=http://www.templecontemporary.info/|title=Temple Contemporary|website=www.templecontemporary.info|language=en|access-date=2018-10-17}} To achieve that goal, Temple Contemporary relies on a "ground-up" programming model. The issues that Temple Contemporary tackles in its gallery exhibitions and other public programming are not determined by its director, but are prompted by a democratic process spearheaded by an advisory council made up of non-Temple-University-based local residents (ranging from high school students to community leaders), Temple University and Tyler faculty faculty members, Temple University and Tyler students and others.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/post/inside-temple-contemporary-qa-rob-blackson|title=Inside Temple Contemporary: Q&A with Rob Blackson|last=admin|date=2015-08-21|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/meet-tyler-dean-susan-cahan|title=Meet Tyler dean Susan Cahan|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://thephiladelphiacitizen.org/rob-blackson-temple-contemporary-2/|title=Temple Contemporary's Rob Blackson Disrupts the Traditional Art Gallery|website=thephiladelphiacitizen.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-17}} Temple Contemporary's community-focused programming that has earned national attention includes "Funeral for a Home" (2014){{Cite web|url=http://funeralforahome.org/|title=Funeral for a Home|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 18, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/05/30/317407504/in-nod-to-history-a-crumbling-philly-row-house-gets-a-funeral|title=In Nod To History, A Crumbling Philly Row House Gets A Funeral|last=|first=|date=|work=NPR's "All Things Considered"|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, an extended commemoration of at-risk urban housing stock and the lives that soon-to-be-demolished homes contain; "reForm" (2014-2015){{Cite web|url=http://reform-project.org/|title=reForm|website=reForm|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/29/arts/design/art-show-captures-the-wrenching-effects-of-closing-a-school.html|title=Art Show Captures the Wrenching Effects of Closing a School|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, a response to the closure of public schools and its impact on urban communities and their children by artist and Tyler faculty member [[Pepón Osorio]]; and "Symphony for a Broken Orchestra" (2017-2018){{Cite web|url=http://symphonyforabrokenorchestra.org/|title=Symphony for a Broken Orchestra|website=symphonyforabrokenorchestra.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/04/arts/music/philadelphia-david-lang-symphony-for-a-broken-orchestra.html|title=A Symphony Breathes Life Into 400 Broken School Instruments|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, a citywide effort to collect, display, repair and return broken instruments belonging to Philadelphia's public schools, highlighted by the composition of music for the broken instruments by composer David Lang and the music's performance by a diverse orchestra of local residents. All three of the projects above were funded in part by the [[Pew Center for Arts & Heritage]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/people/rob-blackson|title=Rob Blackson|last=admin|date=2016-11-30|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/grant/symphony-broken-orchestra|title=Symphony for a Broken Orchestra - GRANT|last=admin|date=2016-11-30|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}. Tyler also hosts a variety of free public lecture series and visiting artist and architect programs, including: * The Critical Dialogue series, a core component of Tyler's MFA program in Painting, Drawing and Sculpture that has been bringing internationally renowned artists, filmmakers, architects, curators, scholars, and writers to campus to work with Tyler students for more than four decades. Past lecturers include [[Vito Acconci]], [[Philip Guston]], [[Rosalind E. Krauss|Rosalind Krauss]], [[Kerry James Marshall]] and [[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]]. * The Jack Wolgin Annual Visiting Artist Symposium, an endowed visiting artist program that brings one of the nation's most influential artists and thinkers to campus to work with Tyler students and present a free lecture each year. Past Jack Wolgin Annual Visiting Artists include [[LaToya Ruby Frazier]], [[Rick Lowe]] and [[Judy Pfaff]].{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/rick-lowe-coming-tyler|title=Rick Lowe coming to Tyler|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}} *The Architecture Alumni Lecture, an endowed series established by Tyler Architecture alumni to honor Brigitte Knowles, professor emerita and former associate dean, by bringing the world's leading architects, landscape architects and designers to campus. Past lecturers include [[David Adjaye]], [[Craig Edward Dykers]], [[Walter Hood]] and [[Clive Wilkinson]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.alumni.temple.edu/s/705/alumni/16/interior.aspx?sid=705&gid=1&pgid=8723&cid=14846&ecid=14846|title=TYL Architecture Alumni Lecture in Honor of Brigitte Knowles|website=www.alumni.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}}{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/blog/brigitte-knowles-honored-sn%C3%B8hetta-lecture-sponsored-architecture-alumni|title=Brigitte Knowles Honored at Snøhetta Lecture Sponsored by Architecture Alumni|website=Tyler School of Art|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} * The Laurie Wagman Lecture Series in Glass, an endowed visiting artist program that brings internationally renowned glass artists to Tyler to work with students and present free public lectures. Past lecturers include [[James Carpenter (architect)|James Carpenter]], [[Doreen Garner]], [[Beth Lipman]] and [[Judith Schaechter|Judith Schaecter]]. == Rankings== [[U.S. News and World Report]]'s annual Best Graduate Schools ranking of "Best Fine Arts (MFA) Schools" lists the Tyler School of Art as No. 15 in the nation, tied with four other institutions. Among public art schools, Tyler is tied for No. 5 in the nation for their graduate programs, and Tyler is the only art school in the Philadelphia region to be ranked in the top 30. Several of Tyler's individual MFA programs also earn national top-10 ranks from U.S. News, including glass (ranked No. 2 in Best Graduate Schools), printmaking (no. 7) and painting/drawing (no. 10). == Notable alumni == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Dennis Adams]], artist *[[Polly Apfelbaum]], artist *[[Timothy App]], painter *[[Bill Beckley]], artist *[[Stanley Bleifeld]], sculptor *[[Moe Brooker]], artist *[[Harriete Estel Berman]], artist *[[Karen Boccalero]], artist, nun *[[Regis Brodie]], artist, [[Skidmore College|Skidmore]] faculty member *[[Donald Camp]], photographer, [[Ursinus College|Ursinus]] faculty member *[[Barbara Chase-Riboud]], artist, novelist, poet *[[Manon Cleary]], painter *[[Cecelia Condit]], artist, [[Wisconsin-Milwaukee]] faculty member *[[Chuck Connelly]], painter *[[Harvey Dinnerstein]], painter, educator *[[Alix Dobkin]], singer-songwriter *[[Trenton Doyle Hancock]], artist *[[Angela Dufresne]], painter, [[RISD]] faculty member *[[Anoka Faruqee]], painter, [[Yale]] faculty member *[[Louise Fishman]], painter *[[Peter Fox (artist)|Peter Fox]], artist *[[Allan Randall Freelon]], artist *[[Nick Fudge]], artist *[[Doreen Garner]], artist *[[Frank Gaylord]], sculptor *[[Deborah Grant (artist)|Deborah Grant]], artist *[[Edgar Heap of Birds]], artist *[[Tim Heidecker]], actor, comedian *[[Jessica Hische]], illustrator, designer *[[Catherine Jansen]], photographer *[[Martha Jackson Jarvis]], artist *[[Irvin Kershner]], film director *[[Simmie Knox]], painter *[[David Levine]], artist, illustrator *[[Stacy Levy]], sculptor *[[E. Jasper]], artist *[[Stanley Lechtzin]], jewelry and metals artist *[[Roberto Lugo]], ceramic artist *[[Winifred Ann Lutz|Winifred Lutz]], sculptor *[[Keith Anthony Morrison]], artist *[[Dona Nelson]], painter *[[Odili Donald Odita]], painter *[[Pepón Osorio]], artist *[[:de:Gerda_Panofsky-Soergel|Gerda Panofsky-Soergel]], art historian *[[Rudolf Staffel]], ceramic artist == History == Arts patron Stella Elkins Tyler (of the [[William Lukens Elkins|Elkins]]/[[Widener family]]) donated her estate in Elkins Park, Pennsylvania, to Temple University in the early 1930s. With an interest in progressive education and a deep appreciation of her mentor, the sculptor Boris Blai, Tyler offered her estate with the expressed wish that, through Boris Blai, it would become an environment for the advancement of the fine arts, scholarly study in the arts and individual creativity. As founding dean of what was then known as the Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts, Blai instilled the school with a commitment to progressive education emphasizing the student's mastery of technique within the framework of a liberal arts curriculum. Blai insisted upon individual attention to each student's needs as the basis of successful teaching. During his 25-year tenure as dean, Blai shaped the school into one of the finest visual arts centers in the country, and his founding ideals still remain paramount to Tyler's educational philosophy. In 1960, Charles Le Clair succeeded Blai. Under Le Clair, the Tyler campus was improved with construction of a residence hall and two studio/classroom buildings. In 1966, the school's name was changed to the Tyler School of Art, and Le Clair founded the Tyler Study Abroad program in Rome, Italy. Tyler's programs at [[Temple University Rome]] remain among the most respected fine arts study abroad programs in Europe today. Temple University Rome has expanded to include a full range of liberal arts, architecture, business and law courses with an emphasis on those relating to Rome, Italy and Europe.{{Cite web|url=https://rome.temple.edu/history/|title=50 YEARS OF TEMPLE ROME – Temple University Rome Campus|website=rome.temple.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-15}} Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Tyler's curriculum continued to grow in response to new definitions of art-making and the role of art in society. New programs and modern facilities in design, ceramics, glass, metals and photography were added. During this time, Tyler established Art History and Art Education departments on Temple's Main Campus in Philadelphia. The pace of change and growth began to accelerate dramatically in the late 1990s. In 1998, Tyler welcomed Temple's Department of Architecture. In 2009, Tyler moved from Elkins Park into a new, 250,000-square-foot building at Temple's Main Campus. Three years later, Architecture moved into a new 50,000-square-foot facility connected to the new Tyler building. Temple's departments of Landscape Architecture & Horticulture and Planning & Community Development became part of Tyler in 2016, for the first time unifying all of the built-environment disciplines at Temple in one academic unit. In 2017, the Tyler School of Art welcomed Susan E. Cahan, who came from Yale University to become first permanent dean of an independent Tyler since the school moved into its new building in 2009. Tyler's leaders: * Boris Blai, dean (1935-1960) * Charles Le Clair, dean (1960-1974) *Donald M. Lantzy, acting dean (1974-1975) *Jack Wasserman, dean (1975-1977) * David Pease, interim dean (1977-1978) and dean (1978-1984) *George Bayliiss, dean (1984-1989) * Rochelle Toner, dean (1989-2002) * Hester Stinnett, acting dean (2002-2005) * Keith Anthony Morrison, dean (2005-2008) * Therese Dolan, interim dean (2008-2009) * Robert Stroker, interim dean and dean of Center for the Arts (2009-2015) * Hester Stinnett, interim dean (2015-2017) * Susan E.
